item.title: Alexis Herman, the first Black secretary of labor in U.S. history, dies at age 77
item.description: Civil rights groups, labor organizations and politicians praised Alexis Herman as a "trailblazer" who fought for the rights of women, Black people and American workers over the course of decades.

item.title: Finally! Shedeur Sanders gets picked by the Cleveland Browns in the NFL draft 5th round
item.description: He had to wait until the fifth round, but Shedeur Sanders, son of Pro Football Hall of Famer Deion Sanders — his coach at the University of Colorado — has finally been drafted by the NFL.

item.title: U.S. judge says 2-year-old apparently deported to Honduras 'with no meaningful process'
item.description: The toddler, a U.S. citizen, was apparently sent to Honduras with her mother and 11-year-old sister, even as a federal judge tried to contact an attorney representing the government.

item.title: A massive explosion at an Iranian port kills 8, injures roughly 750
item.description: A massive explosion and fire rocked a port in southern Iran possibly linked to a shipment of a chemical ingredient used to make missile propellant.

item.title: Built on a rich coffee history, Yemeni cafes find U.S. success and new challenges, too
item.description: Yemen is an ancient birthplace of the coffee trade, and immigrants fleeing its civil war have brought their culture here in the form of cafes. Hundreds of Yemeni coffee shops have opened in the U.S.

item.title: Opinion: Pope Francis's sympathy for migrants was personal
item.description: Pope Francis often spoke with great sympathy for immigrants and refugees. NPR's Scott Simon reminds us that the Pope's father fled Mussolini's Italy, immigrating to Argentina.

item.description: It was their first face-to-face meeting since they argued in front of cameras in the Oval Office in February — and comes as efforts intensify to end Russia's war in Ukraine.
